abstracts.cdata!:
The Disaster Risk Management Development Policy Loan for El Salvador received a satisfactory outcome rating with low or negligible risk to development outcome. The Bank received a moderately satisfactory performance rating while the Borrower received a satisfactory performance rating. There were no restructurings or any significant changes to PDO, indicators, or components during the life of this project. Key lessons learned from this project include five overarching ideas. (1) The effectiveness of the CAT DDO as a source of liquidity after an emergency depends on the detailed identification of the procedures and responsibilities of the
Borrower and the Bank to trigger and process the disbursement. (2) The policy dialogue on DRM could be made more efficient by improving the indicators of the policy matrix. (3) Reporting responsibilities and monitoring arrangements should be agreed with the Borrower in the early stages of the operation to improve the effectiveness and monitoring of the policy measures supported by the DPL. (4) Close Bank supervision is also important to support a successful policy dialogue and DRM outcomes. (5) Finally, the Bank should aim to ensure that the Borrower understands the financial aspects of the CAT DDO instrument, and the consequences of the different options available in relation to interest rates, repayment, and renewal.
